p.s: TroughThrough the whole argument Lady Macbeth tries to convince her husband of killing the King.
Her choice of language is very important at this position.
She starts the argument by using many rhetorical questions in the lines 9-18.
For example she says Was the hope drunk wherein you dressed yourself? (ll. 8-9), which means if he was drunk while planingplanning all this.
By all thisthese retoricalrhetorical questions she tries to insecure Macbeth which causes him to get angry.
She also compares him in line 18 with a poor cat i'th'adage.
This means that he is like a cat which wants fish, but would not get his paws wet.
This comparison also causes him to get angry.
After Macbeth is still not convinced, Lady Macbeth begins her statement again with a rhetorical question (ll. 24-25).

body.p: To start her statement with a rhetorical question causes her to be more convincing.She says that he could be more than a man (l. 28) which causes her to be more convincing because Macbeth is power-crazed.Afterwards Lady Macbeth uses a comparison in the lines 31-36.She tells Macbeth that if she made a promise like him she even would stop breastfeeding her baby and dash his brain out.This comparison should show that Lady Macbeth would bewilling to do what Macbeth is scared of.This should cause to convince Macbeth by using his ego.After Macbeth asks what they should do if they fail, she answers with We fail! (l. 39).This shows that Lady Macbeth does not even think about failing because she is so confident.She also says that he should screw ... (his) ... courage to the sticking place, and we'll not fail (ll. 40-41).This means that if he is brave, they won't fail.This should convince Macbeth again by using his ego.Afterwards Lady Macbeth uses some rhetorical question again in the lines 50-53.What cannot you and I perform upon the unguarded Duncan?What no put upon his spongy officers, who shall bear the guilt of our great quell?. These two rhetorical questions shall show that they only have to kill one man who is only guarded by drunken servants.Also Lady Macbeth uses aan anaphora between these two rhetorical questions.What ...?What ...?(ll. 50-51). This anaphora causecauses Lady Macbeth to be more convincing.

p.s: Overall Lady Macbeth uses many stylistic devices to convince Macbeth.
She also talks way more than Macbeth in this argument, while Macbeth is only answering with one sentence now and then.
